channel.title: Alex Sonneveld
channel.description: A personal blog and writings of an individual by the name of Alex Sonneveld, sometimes known as Sonna throughout the interwebs, a Ruby/Web developer and Video Games enthusiast.

item.title: Welcome to my website
item.description:
So … this has been long time coming. It has been something I have been meaning to do for a while now, however never had the either the motivation or the time to commit to just writing, let alone building a website (despite spinning up a static website generator here and there).

Never really wanted something that be considered bloated or overkill like popular blogging platforms; e.g. WordPress, Drupal, Joomla, etc; nor something custom built on a web framework; like Ruby on Rails or Django; for something as simple as building a few short HTML pages in the form of posts. So something static that did not need too many dependencies like a database and mostly just assisted with pulling together a handful of HTML templates to build a page.

This probably could have been easily achieved by grabbing the boilerplate HTML5 template and adding a couple of paragraph tags to fill out the majority of the post (however that just felt tedious), but during my search of popular programming frameworks, patterns, ideas and just news, I came across Jekyll cause of its integration support within GitHub (since it was created by one of its founders and all).

It exposed me to the idea of Markdown (if I had not already came across it within the excellent Railscasts) and how in combination with Liquid templates achieved the goals that I was looking for, mentioned above. Markdown itself was teasure, its simple to digest syntax helps to cut down on the excess of information throw at you when dealing with HTML, whilst also separating or keeping the concerns of styles to a minimum from the contents of the content (something I find Microsoft Word encourages procastination with).

So far I have already rambled on about why I like Ruby toolchain present in Jekyll, without actually getting to the point of this website and being distracted by fruitless endavours with constently adjusting the style or size of the text in front me. Anywho …

I hope to use this website to write down and scratch out some programming ideas going forward, which has in the past either not been done, done in my head (if even that counts), across multiple ~/Notes Git repositories or folders on different computers or even just loose pieces of paper (oh gosh … soo many paper notes :( ).

One other thing I hope to do. I am going to look more at getting started at programming (again), since my hiatus from work due to mental health reasons, to hopefully teach or help someone indirectly, whilst also looking at comparing and contrasting various programming languages that I have use in the past, to the ones I am using now, as well as others I might us in the future (you know whatever ever popular that week or everyone is jumping ship to).

All that might be a lot to expect of myself, and in way a is sort of proclamation of my New Years Resolution (if I need one), but right now I want this to be more than just a flash in the pan or spur of the moment and look for forward to the rest 2018.

Happy New Year.
